field.name: Solar Energy
field.description: Solar energy generation technologies including photovoltaic systems, concentrated solar power, solar thermal, and related infrastructure for converting sunlight into electricity or heat.

problems.title: Grid Interconnection Queue Backlog Delaying Solar Project Deployment
problems.description: The U.S. electricity grid faces an unprecedented backlog in interconnection queues, with over 2,600 GW of generation capacity—predominantly solar and storage projects—waiting for approval. This represents more than double the current installed U.S. generation capacity. Projects now face average wait times of 3-5 years, with some regions experiencing delays of 7+ years. The withdrawal rate has reached approximately 80%, meaning most proposed projects never reach completion due to queue-related delays and uncertainty. This bottleneck stems from understaffed grid operators, outdated study processes designed for fewer large projects rather than many distributed ones, inadequate transmission infrastructure, and complex multi-party coordination requirements. The backlog is severely constraining the pace of clean energy deployment and threatening climate goals, as projects that could be operational within 1-2 years from a construction standpoint are instead stuck in administrative limbo for half a decade or more.
problems.summary: Over 2,600 GW of solar and storage projects are stuck in grid interconnection queues with 3-7 year wait times, causing 80% project withdrawal rates and severely limiting clean energy deployment.

rootCauses.description: Grid operators are understaffed and under-resourced to process the surge in interconnection applications
rootCauses.evidence: FERC and regional transmission organizations report significant staffing shortages relative to application volumes

rootCauses.description: Legacy study processes designed for a few large power plants cannot efficiently handle thousands of distributed generation projects
rootCauses.evidence: Queue processes were designed decades ago for different generation paradigms

rootCauses.description: Insufficient transmission infrastructure to accommodate new generation in high-resource areas
rootCauses.evidence: Many solar-rich regions lack adequate transmission capacity to export power

rootCauses.description: Speculative projects clogging queues without serious intent to build
rootCauses.evidence: 80% withdrawal rate indicates many projects are not viable or speculative

rootCauses.description: Complex coordination requirements between multiple utilities, RTOs, and regulators
rootCauses.evidence: Multi-party studies and agreements add significant time and complexity

consequences.description: Delayed clean energy deployment threatening climate targets
Stranded development costs for projects that withdraw from queues
Reduced investor confidence in renewable energy projects
Continued reliance on fossil fuel generation
Higher electricity costs for consumers due to constrained supply

existingSolutions.description: Alternative queue management prioritizing projects with site control, financing, and permits
existingSolutions.limitations: May disadvantage smaller developers; requires significant process changes

existingSolutions.name: Increased Grid Operator Staffing
existingSolutions.description: Hiring additional engineers and analysts to process interconnection studies
existingSolutions.limitations: Labor market constraints; training time required; does not address process inefficiencies

solutionGaps.description: Lack of standardized, automated interconnection study tools that can rapidly assess grid impacts
solutionGaps.opportunity: AI/ML-powered grid modeling could dramatically accelerate studies

solutionGaps.description: Insufficient transmission buildout to high-resource solar regions
solutionGaps.opportunity: Proactive transmission planning and construction for renewable energy zones

solutionGaps.description: No effective mechanism to filter out speculative projects early in the process
solutionGaps.opportunity: Meaningful deposits, milestones, and readiness requirements

solutionGaps.description: Limited coordination between federal, state, and utility planning processes
solutionGaps.opportunity: Integrated resource and transmission planning across jurisdictions

problems.title: Solar Panel End-of-Life Recycling Infrastructure Crisis
problems.description: The solar industry faces an imminent waste management crisis as the first generation of mass-deployed solar panels approaches end-of-life. Currently, only about 10% of decommissioned solar panels are recycled, with 90% ending up in landfills. The U.S. is projected to have 1 million tons of solar panel waste by 2030 and up to 10 million tons by 2050, making it the second-largest source of PV waste globally. The core challenge is economic: recycling a silicon PV module costs $15-45, while landfilling costs only $1-5. Solar panels contain valuable materials (silver, copper, silicon, aluminum) worth an estimated $450 million globally by 2030, but extraction at high purity is technically challenging and expensive. Additionally, some panels contain hazardous materials like lead and cadmium that can contaminate soil and groundwater if improperly disposed. Unlike the EU, which has mandated 80% mass recovery through the WEEE Directive, the U.S. lacks comprehensive federal recycling regulations, creating a patchwork of state-level approaches and inadequate recycling infrastructure.
problems.summary: Only 10% of solar panels are recycled due to unfavorable economics ($15-45 recycling vs $1-5 landfill), with the U.S. facing 10 million tons of PV waste by 2050 and lacking federal recycling mandates.

rootCauses.description: Unfavorable economics with recycling costing 3-10x more than landfilling
rootCauses.evidence: NREL data shows $15-45 recycling cost vs $1-5 landfill cost per module

rootCauses.description: Complex laminated construction makes material separation difficult and expensive
rootCauses.evidence: Panels consist of tightly bonded layers of glass, polymers, silicon, and metals

rootCauses.description: Lack of federal recycling mandates or extended producer responsibility requirements
rootCauses.evidence: No U.S. federal equivalent to EU WEEE Directive for solar panels

rootCauses.description: Insufficient recycling infrastructure and facility capacity
rootCauses.evidence: Limited number of specialized PV recycling facilities in North America

rootCauses.description: Low recovered material values relative to extraction costs
rootCauses.evidence: High-purity extraction requires expensive processing that exceeds material value

consequences.description: Accumulation of electronic waste in landfills with potential soil and groundwater contamination
Loss of valuable recoverable materials including silver, copper, and silicon
Reputational damage to solar industry's environmental credentials
Potential release of hazardous materials (lead, cadmium) from improperly disposed panels
Missed opportunity for domestic material supply through circular economy

existingSolutions.limitations: Only applies to EU; compliance costs increase panel prices

existingSolutions.limitations: Limited geographic coverage; capacity constraints; high processing costs

solutionGaps.opportunity: Advanced separation and purification technologies that improve economics

problems.title: Critical Dependence on Chinese-Dominated Solar Supply Chain
problems.description: The global solar photovoltaic supply chain is overwhelmingly controlled by China, which commands over 80% of manufacturing capacity across all key stages: polysilicon production, ingot and wafer manufacturing, cell fabrication, and module assembly. This concentration is projected to reach 95%+ for polysilicon and wafers based on capacity under construction. China's dominance stems from decades of strategic industrial policy, massive subsidies, and resulting economies of scale that have driven costs down by over 80%. The consequence is a significant energy security vulnerability for the U.S. and other nations pursuing clean energy transitions. Even domestic U.S. manufacturing spurred by IRA incentives is threatened, as Chinese overproduction has driven global module prices to unsustainable levels. The Meyer Burger facility in Colorado closed due to inability to compete with Chinese pricing. Chinese firms entering the U.S. market focus on final assembly rather than full-scale production, still importing critical components from Asia. Trade barriers (25-30% tariffs) have created supply shortages and cost increases without successfully building independent supply chains.
problems.summary: China controls 80%+ of global solar manufacturing across all supply chain stages, creating energy security vulnerabilities as U.S. domestic production cannot compete with subsidized Chinese pricing despite IRA incentives.

rootCauses.description: Decades of Chinese strategic industrial policy prioritizing solar as a key sector
rootCauses.evidence: Chinese government has designated solar PV as strategic industry with substantial support

rootCauses.description: Massive Chinese government subsidies enabling below-cost production and market flooding
rootCauses.evidence: Chinese manufacturers sell at prices below production costs to maintain market share

rootCauses.description: Economies of scale achieved through dominant market position
rootCauses.evidence: China is most cost-competitive location for all PV supply chain stages

rootCauses.description: Late and insufficient Western response to build domestic manufacturing capacity
rootCauses.evidence: IRA incentives came after China already achieved dominant position

rootCauses.description: Global demand growth outpacing non-Chinese supply development
rootCauses.evidence: World solar manufacturing capacity exceeds demand by 2-4x, mostly Chinese

consequences.description: Energy security vulnerability for nations dependent on Chinese imports
Collapse of non-Chinese solar manufacturing unable to compete on price
Supply disruption risks from trade disputes or geopolitical tensions
Loss of manufacturing jobs and technological capability in non-Chinese markets
Trade barriers increasing costs and causing supply shortages

problems.title: Solar Industry Policy Uncertainty and Tax Credit Expiration Risk
problems.description: The U.S. solar industry faces significant policy uncertainty that is already constraining investment and development activity. The Inflation Reduction Act's Section 48E and 45Y tax credits for solar will no longer be available after 2027, and the Section 25D residential solar tax credit expires after 2025. Projects must start construction by July 4, 2026 to qualify for credits with a 4-year completion window. This cliff creates boom-bust dynamics as developers rush to safe-harbor projects before deadlines. The residential market is particularly vulnerable, with projections showing a 13% installation decline in 2026 without ITC for customer-owned systems. The inverter market is expected to decline 22% in 2026 due to IRA credit phaseouts. Compounding this is ongoing uncertainty about broader federal policy direction, potential changes to existing incentives, and FEOC (Foreign Entity of Concern) rules affecting supply chain compliance. The base case industry forecast predicts 5% average annual contraction in solar installations between 2025-2030, primarily driven by policy and tariff uncertainty.
problems.summary: Solar tax credits expire 2025-2027, creating 13% residential installation drops and 22% inverter market declines, with industry forecasting 5% annual contraction through 2030 due to policy uncertainty.

rootCauses.description: Time-limited nature of IRA tax credits creating artificial deadlines
rootCauses.evidence: Section 48E/45Y expire after 2027; 25D expires after 2025

rootCauses.description: Political uncertainty about continuation or modification of clean energy incentives
rootCauses.evidence: Changes in administration creating uncertainty about existing policy commitments

rootCauses.description: Complex and evolving FEOC compliance requirements affecting supply chain decisions
rootCauses.evidence: Developers struggling to understand and comply with foreign entity rules

rootCauses.description: Lack of long-term, stable policy framework for clean energy transition
rootCauses.evidence: Stop-start incentive cycles have characterized solar policy for decades

consequences.description: Rush to safe-harbor projects creating supply chain stress and labor shortages
Reduced investor confidence and higher financing costs due to uncertainty
Projected 5% annual installation contraction through 2030
Residential solar market decline as customer-owned ITC expires
Slowed progress toward climate and clean energy goals

problems.title: Solar Module Supply Shortages from Trade Barriers and Tariffs
problems.description: The U.S. solar industry is experiencing acute module supply shortages driven by a complex web of trade barriers, tariffs, and anti-circumvention enforcement. Module imports from Southeast Asian countries (Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam - collectively CMTV) have plummeted from an average of 3.8 GW per month in 2024 to just 1.1 GW per month in Q1 2025 - a 71% decline. Imports from Cambodia have dropped to zero due to high AD/CVD (anti-dumping/countervailing duty) rates. Current tariff rates include 25% on Canada and Mexico, 30% on China, and 10% on all other countries. Many installers report manufacturers and distributors are sold out of both domestic and imported modules through year-end 2026. The supply crunch has forced the near-term residential solar outlook to be downgraded by 2% in 2025 and 8% in 2026. While tariffs aim to protect domestic manufacturing, the U.S. lacks sufficient domestic capacity to meet demand, creating a gap that cannot be quickly filled. The rapid proliferation of trade actions poses challenges in maintaining steady supply and managing costs, affecting project economics and development timelines.
problems.summary: Solar module imports dropped 71% due to tariffs and AD/CVD enforcement, with suppliers sold out through 2026 while domestic manufacturing cannot fill the supply gap.

rootCauses.description: High AD/CVD tariff rates on major import sources making many suppliers uneconomic
rootCauses.evidence: Cambodia imports dropped to zero; CMTV imports down 71%

rootCauses.description: Insufficient domestic manufacturing capacity to replace imports
rootCauses.evidence: U.S. module capacity insufficient to meet demand despite IRA incentives

rootCauses.description: Long lead times to build new domestic manufacturing capacity

problems.title: Skilled Workforce Shortage Constraining Solar Industry Growth
problems.description: The solar industry faces a critical skilled labor shortage that is actively constraining project deployment and growth. Industry surveys indicate that 37% of solar companies cite lack of skilled workers as a primary business challenge. The sector needs to add over 1 million workers by 2030 to meet projected demand, but struggles with high turnover rates, insufficient training infrastructure, and competition from other construction and energy sectors. Key gaps exist in electrical work, project management, engineering, and specialized installation skills for emerging technologies like battery storage integration. The shortage is particularly acute in certain regions and for utility-scale projects requiring large, coordinated workforces. Rising wages have helped attract workers but also increase project costs, affecting economics. The boom-bust nature of solar policy creates workforce instability, as workers leave the industry during downturns and are difficult to recruit back. Training programs exist but cannot scale fast enough to meet demand, and there is limited coordination between employers, educational institutions, and workforce development agencies.
problems.summary: 37% of solar companies cite skilled labor shortage as a primary challenge, with the industry needing 1M+ workers by 2030 while facing high turnover and insufficient training infrastructure.

problems.title: Long-Duration Energy Storage Gap Limiting Solar Grid Integration
problems.description: While lithium-ion batteries have become cost-effective for short-duration storage (2-4 hours), the solar industry lacks economically viable long-duration energy storage (LDES) solutions needed for reliable grid integration at high renewable penetration levels. As solar provides an increasing share of electricity (58% of new U.S. capacity in 2025), the grid faces growing challenges with daily and seasonal variability. Current lithium-ion technology cannot economically address multi-day storage needs during extended cloudy periods or seasonal variations in solar output. Alternative LDES technologies (flow batteries, compressed air, hydrogen, thermal storage) remain expensive, with limited commercial deployment and uncertain cost trajectories. This storage gap creates grid integration challenges including curtailment during peak solar hours, reliance on natural gas peakers for evening ramps, and difficulty achieving very high renewable penetration without dispatchable backup. The Department of Energy's Long Duration Storage Shot targets 90% cost reduction, but achieving this requires significant R&D breakthroughs and manufacturing scale-up over many years.
problems.summary: Solar grid integration is limited by lack of economically viable long-duration storage beyond 4 hours, requiring 90% cost reductions in LDES technologies to enable high renewable penetration.

rootCauses.description: Fundamental cost-duration tradeoff in battery technologies favoring short duration
rootCauses.evidence: Lithium-ion costs scale linearly with duration, making long duration uneconomic

rootCauses.description: Early-stage maturity of alternative LDES technologies
rootCauses.evidence: Flow batteries, hydrogen, thermal storage still in demonstration phase

rootCauses.description: Lack of market structures properly valuing long-duration reliability services
rootCauses.evidence: Current capacity markets and ancillary services designed for conventional generation

rootCauses.description: Investment uncertainty slowing LDES manufacturing scale-up
rootCauses.evidence: Limited commercial deployments create chicken-and-egg problem for cost reduction

consequences.description: Solar curtailment during peak generation hours wasting clean energy
Continued reliance on natural gas peakers for evening demand ramps
Ceiling on achievable renewable penetration without dispatchable backup
Higher system costs from maintaining fossil backup capacity
Grid reliability risks during extended low-solar periods

problems.title: Residential Solar Affordability and Financing Access Barriers
problems.description: The residential solar market faces significant affordability and financing barriers that limit adoption, particularly among low-and-moderate income households. While rooftop solar can provide long-term savings, the high upfront costs ($15,000-$30,000 for a typical system) create substantial barriers. The residential market has experienced a 31% installation decline, driven by higher interest rates affecting solar loans and leases, as well as reduced net metering compensation in key markets. The expiration of the Section 25D residential tax credit after 2025 will remove a 30% federal incentive for customer-owned systems, projected to cause a 13% installation decline in 2026. Many potential adopters lack the tax liability to fully utilize tax credits, the credit score to qualify for favorable financing, or homeownership status enabling rooftop installation. Third-party ownership models (leases and PPAs) help address some barriers but reduce customer savings and have faced regulatory challenges in some states. The result is a solar adoption pattern concentrated among higher-income homeowners, missing the potential for broader economic and environmental benefits.
problems.summary: Residential solar faces 31% installation declines from high interest rates and expiring tax credits, with affordability barriers excluding low-income households from $15,000-$30,000 system costs.

rootCauses.description: High upfront system costs creating significant financial barrier

rootCauses.description: Reduced net metering compensation in key markets

problems.title: Solar Land Use Competition and Agricultural Co-Existence Challenges
problems.description: Utility-scale solar development increasingly faces land use conflicts, particularly competition with agricultural uses and community opposition to large-scale installations. While solar currently uses only about 0.23% of county land on average nationwide, individual projects can be large (hundreds to thousands of acres), creating localized impacts and opposition. Concerns include loss of prime farmland, visual impacts, property value effects, and ecosystem disruption. Agrivoltaics—the co-location of solar with agricultural activities—offers a promising solution but faces practical challenges including higher installation and maintenance costs, crop selection limitations, and operational complexity. Many localities have implemented restrictive zoning or moratoriums on solar development in response to community concerns. The challenge is balancing clean energy deployment needs with legitimate agricultural, environmental, and community interests. Poor siting decisions and inadequate community engagement have generated backlash that affects the entire industry, while well-designed projects can provide benefits including pollinator habitat, sheep grazing, and compatible crop cultivation beneath elevated panels.
problems.summary: Utility-scale solar faces growing land use conflicts with agriculture and community opposition, while agrivoltaics solutions remain costly and complex to implement at scale.

rootCauses.description: Large land footprint of utility-scale solar creating visible local impacts
rootCauses.evidence: Individual projects can span hundreds to thousands of acres

rootCauses.description: Competition for productive agricultural land in solar-rich regions
rootCauses.evidence: Solar development often targets flat, cleared agricultural land

rootCauses.description: Inadequate community engagement and benefit-sharing in some projects
rootCauses.evidence: Community backlash often stems from feeling excluded from decisions

rootCauses.description: Higher costs and complexity of agrivoltaic dual-use designs
rootCauses.evidence: Elevated panels and wider spacing increase costs 10-30%

rootCauses.description: Fragmented local zoning authority creating inconsistent development standards
rootCauses.evidence: County-by-county regulations vary widely in requirements and restrictions

consequences.description: Local moratoriums and restrictive zoning limiting development options
Project delays and cancellations from community opposition
Loss of agricultural land and food production capacity
Reputational damage to solar industry from contentious projects
Increased development costs from longer permitting and engagement processes

existingSolutions.name: Agrivoltaics

existingSolutions.limitations: Higher costs; limited compatible crops; operational complexity

existingSolutions.name: Community Benefit Agreements

existingSolutions.limitations: Negotiations can be lengthy; benefits may not address all concerns

existingSolutions.name: Brownfield and Disturbed Land Siting
existingSolutions.description: Prioritizing development on contaminated or already-disturbed sites
existingSolutions.limitations: Limited suitable sites; may have higher development costs

solutionGaps.description: No standardized framework for balancing solar and agricultural land use
solutionGaps.opportunity: State-level guidelines for responsible solar siting

solutionGaps.description: Limited research on optimizing agrivoltaic crop-solar combinations
solutionGaps.opportunity: Expanded agricultural research on dual-use systems

solutionGaps.description: Insufficient tools for quantifying community benefits and impacts
solutionGaps.opportunity: Standardized impact assessment and benefit-sharing frameworks

problems.title: Solar Panel Efficiency and Performance Degradation Limitations
problems.description: Despite significant improvements, commercial solar panel efficiency remains limited, with most crystalline silicon panels achieving 18-22% conversion efficiency. The theoretical maximum (Shockley-Queisser limit) is around 33% for single-junction cells. This efficiency gap means more land, materials, and installation labor are required to generate a given amount of power. Additionally, panels experience degradation over their 25-30 year lifespan, typically losing 0.5-1% of output annually, with faster degradation in hot climates or from manufacturing defects. Performance can also be affected by soiling (dust, bird droppings), shading, temperature effects (panels lose efficiency in heat), and inverter issues. While premium panels with higher efficiency exist, they carry significant cost premiums that affect project economics. For rooftop applications, limited roof space makes efficiency particularly important, as maximum generation must be achieved from available area. Emerging technologies like perovskites, tandem cells, and bifacial panels offer efficiency improvements but face durability, stability, or cost challenges limiting widespread adoption.
problems.summary: Commercial solar panels achieve only 18-22% efficiency vs 33% theoretical maximum, while degrading 0.5-1% annually over 25-30 year lifespans, with emerging high-efficiency technologies facing durability challenges.

rootCauses.description: Fundamental thermodynamic limits on single-junction solar cell efficiency
rootCauses.evidence: Shockley-Queisser limit of ~33% for single-junction cells

rootCauses.description: Cost-efficiency tradeoffs limiting commercial adoption of advanced cell designs
rootCauses.evidence: High-efficiency panels carry significant cost premiums

rootCauses.description: Material degradation mechanisms over panel lifetime
rootCauses.evidence: UV exposure, thermal cycling, and moisture cause gradual performance loss

rootCauses.description: Stability challenges with emerging high-efficiency technologies
rootCauses.evidence: Perovskites degrade rapidly; tandem cells are expensive

consequences.description: Greater land and material requirements for given power output
Higher installation costs per watt due to more panels needed
Limited rooftop generation potential in space-constrained applications
Declining output over system lifetime reducing returns

existingSolutions.name: PERC and TOPCon Cell Technology
existingSolutions.description: Advanced cell architectures improving efficiency over standard cells
existingSolutions.limitations: Approaching practical limits; incremental improvements

existingSolutions.name: Bifacial Panels
existingSolutions.description: Panels capturing light from both sides for increased energy yield
existingSolutions.limitations: Requires appropriate installation conditions; higher cost

existingSolutions.name: Anti-Soiling Coatings
existingSolutions.description: Surface treatments reducing dust accumulation and cleaning needs
existingSolutions.limitations: Adds cost; effectiveness varies by environment

solutionGaps.description: No commercially viable technology to significantly exceed current efficiency limits
solutionGaps.opportunity: Tandem and multi-junction cells at competitive costs

solutionGaps.description: Perovskite stability remains unsolved for commercial deployment
solutionGaps.opportunity: Encapsulation and material engineering for 25+ year stability

solutionGaps.description: Limited ability to predict and prevent degradation failures
solutionGaps.opportunity: Advanced monitoring and predictive maintenance systems

problems.title: Grid Curtailment and Negative Pricing Events from Solar Oversupply
problems.description: As solar penetration increases, grids are experiencing growing periods of oversupply during peak solar hours, leading to curtailment (forced reduction of solar output) and negative wholesale electricity prices. In California, the 'duck curve' phenomenon has intensified, with midday oversupply followed by steep evening ramps requiring fast-ramping generation. CAISO has experienced numerous hours of negative prices, effectively meaning solar generators must pay to deliver power. This represents wasted clean energy and undermines project economics that depend on selling generated power. The problem stems from solar's coincident generation profile (all panels produce at the same time), limited storage and demand flexibility, and grid operating constraints. Curtailment rates have reached 5-10% of potential solar generation in high-penetration markets. Without adequate solutions, increasing solar deployment will face diminishing returns, as each additional project generates during already-oversupplied hours. The challenge requires coordinated solutions across storage, demand response, transmission, and market design.
problems.summary: Solar oversupply causes increasing curtailment (5-10% of generation) and negative pricing events in high-penetration markets, wasting clean energy and undermining project economics.

rootCauses.description: Coincident generation profile with all solar producing during same hours
rootCauses.evidence: Solar generation peaks midday when demand may not be at maximum

rootCauses.description: Insufficient storage capacity to shift solar production to high-demand periods
rootCauses.evidence: Storage deployment lags solar deployment

rootCauses.description: Limited demand flexibility to absorb midday generation
rootCauses.evidence: Industrial and commercial loads not yet responsive to real-time pricing

rootCauses.description: Transmission constraints preventing export to regions with demand
rootCauses.evidence: Limited inter-regional transmission capacity

rootCauses.description: Market structures designed for dispatchable generation
rootCauses.evidence: Day-ahead markets don't optimally integrate variable generation

consequences.description: Wasted clean energy from curtailed solar generation
Reduced project revenues from curtailment and negative prices
Diminishing returns from additional solar deployment
Grid operational challenges from steep ramping requirements
Need for fast-ramping gas plants for evening demand

existingSolutions.name: Battery Storage Co-Location
existingSolutions.description: Pairing solar with batteries to shift generation to higher-value hours
existingSolutions.limitations: Adds capital cost; limited to 4-hour shift typically

existingSolutions.name: Time-of-Use Rates
existingSolutions.description: Pricing structures incentivizing demand shift away from solar peak
existingSolutions.limitations: Limited customer response; doesn't address wholesale market

existingSolutions.name: Western Energy Imbalance Market
existingSolutions.description: Real-time market enabling power sharing across Western utilities
existingSolutions.limitations: Limited to balancing; not full integration

solutionGaps.description: Insufficient long-duration storage to shift solar across days
solutionGaps.opportunity: Cost-effective multi-day storage technologies

solutionGaps.description: Limited industrial demand response capability
solutionGaps.opportunity: Automated, price-responsive industrial loads

solutionGaps.description: Inadequate transmission to export excess solar
solutionGaps.opportunity: Inter-regional HVDC transmission buildout

solutionGaps.description: Market designs not optimized for variable generation
solutionGaps.opportunity: Improved forecasting, faster markets, flexible products
